On Monday, Apr 28, 2003, at 16:30 US/Eastern, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> What about Ant makes it difficult to manage widely-ranging  
> dependencies and tasks? If Ant can do what make can do, when why is  
> Ant any less suited to building the JDK/JVM than make?

Nothing in the architecture of Ant per se. Compiling native  
executables, however, requires quite a bit of knowledge of the local  
platform: What options to pass to the compiler, where to find the  
compiler, what libraries are needed, how to make shared libraries, how  
to package executables (resources, bundles and so forth), etc.

Make is missing much of this as well, but most people do not use raw  
make for cross-platform work. There are a lot of tools out there which  
already have the logic to ferret out many of these settings and many  
companies already have an in-house tool for their projects. These  
tools, by and large, know how to write makefiles. This logic would need  
to be coded into Ant (or an add-on) and and Ant would need to interact  
heavily with a host of native tools to accomplish this anyway. The  
cross-platform/architecture neutral nature of Ant ends up buying very  
little in a job like that.

Ant will probably inch into this area over time, but it is not quite  
there yet.
